story: He will also propose relaxing planning laws to encourage businesses and launch a new Future High Streets Fund.His support package for high streets follows the demise of Woolworths and BHS as well as this week's revelation that Debenhams has made a near &pound500million loss.It comes as a massive victory for the 's Save Our High Streets crusade, which has been rallying support for measures to support struggling shops.Estimated Mr Hammond's Budget measures will include &pound900million of immediate business rate relief for 496,000 small retailers.                New fight to halt demise of the high street                Britain's high streets will be given new lease of lifeThe measure is expected to reduce annual bills by about a third and follows nearly &pound10billion of business rates relief announced by the Treasury since 2016.Examples of the effects of the measures for small businesses released by the Treasury yesterday estimated that a pub in Sheffield with a rateable value of &pound37,750 would save &pound6,178 on business rates next year.A newsagent in Moseley, Birmingham with a rateable value of &pound14,250 would save &pound1,749.Mr Hammond will also pledge &pound650million for the Future High Streets Fund which will seek to modernise high streets and ensure they can remain at the heart of the local communities.It will be designed to help councils and business leaders work together to adapt to changing shopping habits in the era of the online retail boom.Britain&rsquos high streets have been facing unprecedented pressure with stores closing (Image: Oli ScarffGetty Images)Mr Hammond will also respond to pleas from campaigners and business leaders for a shake-up in town planning rules to allow new mixed-use businesses on the high street and the conversion of under-used retail units into offices and homes.A new &pound2million High Streets Taskforce to offer support and advice to help revitalise high streets is also included in the Treasury plans.Business leaders welcomed the Budget package last night.Hannah Essex, of the British Chambers of Commerce, said: We're delighted that the Chancellor has heeded our calls to abandon the uprating of business rates for the high street for the next two years, and gone further by cutting bills for the vast majority of high street firms. It's crucial that we support our town centres as they find their place in a changing world.                Claire&rsquos &lsquoset to close raft of stores&rsquo latest blow British high street                Debenhams &lsquoto report &pound500M LOSS - 50 stores to CLOSE'Mr Hammond will also pledge &pound650million for the Future High Streets Fund (Image: John StillwellPA Wire)An alarming number of high street firms, both large and small, are closing or being earmarked for closure.This deterioration has cost thousands of jobs since the start of 2018.Mike Cherry, chairman of the Federation of Small Businesses, said: In the lead up to the Budget, we've been urging the Government to provide targeted support to struggling small firms on our high streets.This announcement shows the Chancellor has listened and this relief is a welcome step in getting the urgent help that all small businesses need.Small firms are the lifeblood of our high street. They are under a huge amount of pressure with current business rates bills adding to that.As Waitrose announces closures across the country. We take a look at the retail giants who have closed high street stores in recent years.                    Getty Images1 of 13Waitrose will close five stores across the UK this autumnCOMMENT BY ROBERT HALFONTHIS Budget presents a vital opportunity for the Government to wade through the fog of Brexit and set out some powerful measures to help workers up and down our country.On Monday, the Chancellor's spending announcements must confront the four challenges facing our nation: cutting the cost of living, building a skills and apprenticeships nation, guaranteeing affordable housing for millions of people and addressing our health and social care needs.Struggled For a number of years, families across Britain have struggled under the difficult economy.Although the Government cut taxes for lower earners and introduced the national living wage, they must use this Budget to really help those just about managing.The Treasury should continue cutting income taxes for those on low wages and do more to reduce spiralling utility bills.The Budget must help commuters with the extortionate cost of train fares, by introducing tax allowances for regular train travellers and season ticket-holders.Robert Halfon, MP for Harlow (Image: PA ArchivePA Images)Surely, it is time to scrap the NHS stealth tax on hospital car parking charges, which would cost just &pound200million a year to sort.The money could be found from the &pound1billion that the NHS say they will save in hospital procurement each year.When it comes to the NHS, it is good news that Theresa May has pledged &pound20 billion extra a year.However, we still face under-funding for Britain's biggest killer dementia.If just a fraction of the &pound269 million (rightly) invested in combating cancer was replicated for dementia care and research, this funding would transform the lives of hundreds of thousands of Alzheimer's sufferers.If the Chancellor really wanted to be radical and bold, the Government could scrap the &pound39billion earmarked for the EU, which would mean even more money for schools and hospitals and release funds for significant tax cuts.Robert Halfon is MP for Harlow

title: Brexit news Daniel Hannan EU citizens vote right UK withdrawal patriotism citizenship
story: Daniel Hannan last week claimed in a leaked WhatsApp message to have seen copies of Government files proposing EU nationals receive voting rights in the UK after Brexit.The Conservative MEP insisted the proposal would erode the idea of national citizenship &ndash arguing the British Government should treat EU citizens like any other overseas national..Speaking to LBC, Mr Hannan said: By virtue of owning citizenship you have certain rights and obligations, if you start automatically giving the franchise to people who are not within that citizenship then you might as well not have any concept of national citizenship at all.There&rsquoll be some who now say &lsquowell, we should have the right to vote anyway,&rsquo and I would say, in that case, make a commitment to the country and apply for UK citizenship. We&rsquod love to have you.                SNP politician openly admits existence of MEP PLOT to thwart Brexit                BREXIT LIVE: Labour could back Norway-style transition deal But if you&rsquore not prepared to do that then please stop telling us what rules we should run our elections by.Mr Hannan claimed the British Government is planning to adopt this proposal as part of a bizarre strategy to maintain close alignment with Brussels.He added: What we can&rsquot do is carry on as if we were still in the EU, which is the proposition that our negotiators have incredibly been pushing for in these Brexit talks.They said &lsquook, we will cease to be EU citizens but lets roll everything over as if we still were.&rsquo That seems to me an absolutely bizarre position for Britain to be asking for.Brexit news: Mr Hannan said EU nationals should not be allowed to vote in the UK (Image: CNBC&bull)Around 3.2 million EU citizens live in the UK, with 1.3 million Brits across the EU.In July the Brexit Select Committee in the House of Commons noted Brussels had refused to consider striking an agreement to maintain voting rights after withdrawal.A Government spokesman said: This is not within the scope of the Withdrawal Agreement.We have always been clear that the voting rights of both UK nationals living in the EU and EU nationals living in the UK should be considered together and that we're committed to doing bilateral deals to achieve this.The British Government has set aside a &pound9 million grant to help organisations working with vulnerable EU citizens who need extra support.Voluntary and community organisations will use the money to inform people about settled-status applications. It will also be used to help people complete their applications.

title: google earth us government ufo area 51 tonopah test range
story: Nick Pope, who used to work for the government&rsquos specialist UFO department, has said the discovery the search engine giant did not update images of the Tonopah Test Range for eight years is &ldquomurky.Using his insider background of how governments want to keep such facilities out of the public&rsquos knowledge, he has speculated the reason behind the blackout was because the American government kept top secret information and crashed UFOs.The search giant normally updates satellite images of every part of the continental United States every 60 days but no fresh photos of the Nevada facility appear on Google Earth between 2008 and 2016, it has emerged.This is despite most other military bases in the US being regularly logged.                'Secret Area 51 airline' flies special planes from Las Vegas                UFO PROOF: &lsquoStrange anomaly&rsquo spotted near Jupiter in shock NASA imagesMr Pope told the Sun Online that the base is close to the infamous Area 51, which is why he thinks the US government wanted Google&rsquos cameras to ignore the facility.He said: Because of its proximity to the infamous Area 51, this has understandably started all sorts of conspiracy theories in the UFO community.Could this super-secret location be where the US government hides crashed UFOs?&nbsp&ldquoOr is it where the next generation of stealth aircraft, drones and hypersonic weapons are developed and tested?Nick Pope believes Google and the US government blocked satellite images of the site (Image: Nick Pope)Either way the US government is hugely concerned - and understandably so.This is all quite murky. Either as a consequence of federal law, or through a 'gentleman's agreement', Google andor the third party providers from whom they obtain satellite imagery have ensured that the public won't see up-to-date images of the Tonopah Test Range.Along with drones flown by hobbyists, the easy availability of high-quality satellite imagery has caused immense problems for the military and the intelligence community.It's given people a window on a world that was previously closed to them.The Tonopah Test range is home to some of the US government&rsquos most secret projects (Image: UIG via Getty Images)Simply put, these technologies make it more difficult for the government to hide things.Having worked in the MoD for 21 years I well understand the need for secrecy, and indeed my final posting was to the Directorate of Defence Security.While I understand that people are naturally curious about what's going on at Tonopah, the problem with people's 'right to know' is that once information is in the public domain, it's seen by everyone: not just UFO researchers and aviation enthusiasts, but the Russians, the Chinese, the Iranians, the North Koreans, ISIS and all sorts of other non-state actors who may not have the best of intentions.The desert army barracks have long been the subject of mystery after it was reported the range has been used for secret government aerospace and weapons testing since the 1950s, including the development of the iconic stealth bombers.Aerial shot of the airbase in the Nevada desert (Image: Google)A spokesperson for Google denied any censorship of the base in a statement.The company said: &ldquoGoogle Earth didn&rsquot censor this area in Nevada.Our satellite imagery is licensed from third party providers which are commercially available and are not the property of Google.We update imagery by prioritising areas that are most popular with users while complying with local and federal laws.

title: go vape e cigs better than regular cigarettes
story: But it isn’t.They also think that because you are inhaling nicotine in the vapour of e-cigarettes you are just as likely to get lung cancer as you would smoking tobacco.You are not.There are also worries that vaping will act as a gateway for young people, who have never smoked, to progress to traditional cigarettes and ruin their health as a result.They are fears, too, that it will “normalise” smoking again just when public health campaigns are managing to help more people permanently quit smoking than ever before.All the evidence, however, says that this just is not the case.Don’t get me wrong, as a doctor I’d prefer itnobody smoked OR vaped.Years ago, as medical students, who should have known better, many of us smoked a little — often to disguise the awful, lingering smell of the cadavers we had to dissect in the anatomy room.But we soon stopped when we saw with our own eyes what the long-term effects of smoking did to the human body.In the Pathology Museum we would see a nice healthy pink lung sat pickled in a jar of formaldehyde right next to another lung, black with tar and soot from smoking, at the centre of which was a hard, pearly white grapefruit-sized knuckle of cancer with tentacles reaching out into other adjacent organs including the liver and brain.Smoking kills.Later, as qualied doctors on the wards, we saw the horrendous consequences of it.People who could not breathe without oxygen tanks, people suffering heart attacks or strokes, or undergoing amputations or voicebox removal for throat cancer.We saw — and still see — the damage done to unborn babies of expectant mothers, who remain addicted, and the increased risk of chest and ear infections from passive smoking, and meningitis and leukaemia in infants, who live in smoking households.The medical evidence is irrefutable. Smoking tobacco is bad news.But vaping is dferent.You heat up a solution called an e-liquid, which typically contains nicotine, a propellant called propylene glycol and or vegetable glycerin and flavourings.What you don’t do is burn tobacco or produce tar or carbon monoxide — two of the most harmful elements of all in tobacco smoke.Sure, some vapes may contain a fraction of some of the harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but they are present at much lower levels,detectable at all.So are they safe  According to all the international medically-reviewed evidence from such expert organisations as Public Health England, the Royal Colleges of Physicians and General Practitioners, the British Medical Association and Cancer Research UK, e-cigarettes are at least  per cent safer than traditional cigarettes.The American Cancer Society and the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine both agree with them.Yes, the nicotine, of course, is addictive. But so what  So is caffeine, even eating.Contrary to popular belief, nicotine does not give you cancer and it is relatively harmless generally.Apparently only  per cent of the population know this.Happily, there is no evidence of harm to other people from vaping and,used instead of nicotine replacement gum or patches, may even help expectant mums remain smoke-free in the long term.As a doctor I don’t want any young person or non-nicotine user to try vaping. Ever. Period.As it happens, regular use of e-cigs among “never” smokers is still very rare at just . per cent.But look at what they’ve done to help tobacco smokers quit.In the UK, .million vapers have quit smoking completely and more than , have given up both smoking and vaping.In fact, this is Britain’s most popular method of quitting with two-thirds stopping successfully when used alongside professional stop-smoking NHS support.In this country we have some of the strictest regulations in the world.E-cigs are subject to minimum standards of quality and safety as well as clear packaging and labelling requirements.All ingredients have to be notied, advertising is prohibited in media such as television, newspapers and magazines, it is illegal to sell them to under s and to adults intending to pass them on to under s.That is responsible regulation whichever way you look at it.This month’s national Stoptober campaign recommends using e- cigarettes as a stop-smoking aid andit helps some of the million smokers in the UK kick the habit for good then perhaps doctors like me will see fewer people in our surgeries struggling to breath or devastated by a cancer diagnosis.AndI see any ex-smoking patients of mine having a quiet vape outside my surgery door, I shall give them a heartfelt pat on the back and cherish the fact that there will be one less nasty fag end polluting the street.NICOTINE contained in e-liquids is a highly addictive substance that raises blood pressure and spikes your adrenalin, increasing the chances of having a heart attack.This is particularly worrying as we see a number of iniduals who are constantly vaping, especially as it is seen as more convenient and cost-effective than lighting up a cigarette, as well as being considered more socially acceptable to vape indoors.While vaping appears to be safer than cigarettes, the truth is that it hasn’t been around long enough for us to know the potential damage it can cause to our health.The long-term effects of the chemicals contained in e-liquids haven’t been examined.However, I have looked into ious research that has been carried out on certain e-liquids that were found to contain substances that can cause damage to the immune system and are linked to other health conditions such as cancer.Vaping isn’t great for your oral health either.It’s common for vaping to cause a dry mouth, and I’ve met a number of iniduals who have developed oral thrush, most likely caused by vaping.Although nicotine does not have a colour, it becomes yellow when combined with oxygen which could lead to tooth discolouration.As nicotine is a vasocon-strictor, it limits blood flow in oral tissue, which can cause gum disease and bad breath.As time goes on, I am reading new research which proves vaping has a negative effect on health.To what extent, only time will tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 50 a week boost to universal credit budget 2018
story: MPs are pressuring the Chancellor to reverse cuts to the welfare budget in next week’s fiscal statement, which could make le easier for up to , Brits.The cuts were made under ex-Chancellor George Osborne, and would mean that some Brits won’t be better off under the new Universal Credit system.The rollout, which has been plagued with problems so far, is set to be take place across the whole country next year.New analysis from the Resolution Foundation shows thatthe cuts to work allowances were reversed back to the sort of system that was in place before, around , fewer people would lose out.Most would be at least £ a week better offministers ed to the old system - showing the cuts have dramatically tipped the balance askew between winners and losers under Universal Credit.Universal Credit replaces the following benefits:The government claims around three million working households would see cash gains from Universal Credit.Treasury officials said a couple with two children where one parent earns £, a year would benefit by £.A single parent with one child and no housing costs earning £, a year will get £ more, officials claimed.If you receive any of these benefits, you can’t claim Universal Credit at the same time - you will be moved to Universal Credit when it is introduced in your area.Whether you can claim Universal Credit depends on where you live and your circumstances.Currently, Universal Credit is mainly claimed by the unemployed, or those on a low income.Former Work and Pensions Secretary Iain Duncan-Smith announced the introduction of a Universal Credit in  designed to simply the benefits system and improve work incentives - making it the landmark policy of his time in government.At the moment the think tank estimated that around .million are expected to be worse off when they go onto the new programme - and .million of those poorer by more than £ a week.Butthe cuts were reversed, that number would be slashed dramatically.Insiders are confident the Treasury will make the move to try and quell a growing Tory rebellion over the flagship benefits programme.Tory MP Robert Halfon, part of the group pressuring the Chancellor to think again, told The Sun Online: Universal Credit should be about getting working people out of the poverty trap, not letting them fall through it.It is vital that the Chancellor makes it history and ensures that UC does what it says on the tin - helping the lower paid get on the jobs and financial security ladder of opportunity.Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.Millions more are set to go onto Universal Credit in the coming months - as it continues its rollout across the country.But last week it was revealed that its set to be paused in order to try and fix some of the problems in the system - and more money could be pumped in to make sure that Brits don’t lose out.Many claimants say they don’t get their payments under the new system for many weeks after they are told they will - and end up being pushed into debt as a result.Some are forced into arrears on their rent and bills - and others have even had to resort to prostitution as a result, one MP said.

title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. There’ll be nothing funny for the Irish economyyour cack-handed comedy routine stops you trading with your closest neighbour.It’s getting serious. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. The medieval process to deal with complaints simply cannot stand.The hypocrisy of MPs, who interfere in workplaces across the country on a daily basis, is staggering.The insufferable Speaker John Bercow has shown no appetite to give Commons staff the rights they deserve.Parliament must act.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: freedom of the press sun says gagging claims
story: Yesterday, it was revealed that the Dailyhas been stopped from revealing the name of a prominent businessman who — on at least five occasions — has used non-disclosure agreements and hush money to silence allegations against him.Is it in the public interest for a loaded businessman to be able to silence the Press by spending half a million quid on legal proceedings Or for the public to know what he’s been accused of, and paid handsome sums to keep it quiet Ask yourself this:a member of your family was applying for a job working for him, wouldn’t you want to know The #MeToo scandal showed just how far powerful figures will go to keep their victims schtum. But it’s not just Harvey Weinstein and Hollywood.Over the past year, we’ve seen the High Court impose serious reporting restrictions on police arrests and a bid by Press-hating tycoon Max Mosley to wipe his fascist past out of history citing the ‘right to be forgotten’.It will be you, the public, who lose outthe rich and powerful stop us doing our job.GIVE us a date, Prime Minister.No, not for your departure. But for the end of the transition period.We are wary of it lasting a day beyond .If the PM has any hope of getting a deal through Parliament, the transition must have a legally-binding end date.Anything less would be the definition of a bad deal — and no deal is better than a bad deal.DOES John Bercow have no shame With every day he sits in the Speaker’s chair he discredits Parliament.His refusal to take allegations of bullying and harassment seriously is an embarrassment at the heart of our democracy.Parliament has a ready-made replacement for this rhino-hided oaf in Lindsay Hoyle — respected across the House.Bercow must go. Now.TURKISH supremo Recep Erdogan can spare us the holier than thou act on human rights.What happened to Jamal Khashoggi at the hands of the Saudis is disgraceful. But Erdogan’s record of political purges and locking up journalists is not far off.He has more in common with the regime in Riyadh than he’d like to think.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit no deal nothing to be afraid of
story: Steve Baker urged the Chancellor to show us your workings and said Britain shouldnt be afraid of No Deal as le would be broadly unchanged.Philip Hammonds Treasury has estimated that No Deal Brexit would harm the economy seriously, and we should avoid it as much as possible.Ministers insist they are still working to get a deal, but are ready to step up No Deal prep soonthey dont make progress.Mr Baker told The : Show us your workings Mr Hammond.The reputation of Government economic forecasting after ious rounds of Project Fear really is in the gutter.He said that No Deal Brexit, while it has some negative effects, is broadly neutral.No, we shouldnt be afraid. What kind of posture is it as a great country to go on forward being afraid  Im not afraid of anything.He said that forecasts have predicted that there would only be a small dip in the economywe left without a deal.But he added that Treasury forecasts were far gloomier, predicting a % drop in GDP.People think these forecasts are scripture, they are not, he added.The news comes on the same day as separate economic forecasts said that Britains economy could slow down to its lowest level in a decadewe leave the EU with no trade deal.But the National Institute for Economic and Social Research, which did the study, uses the same economic model as the Treasury.They predicted that a No Deal would push Brexit growth down to . per cent in  - not seen since the  crash.He said in a WhatsApp message to other MEPs that it would give voting rights to all EU citizens in England and Northern Ireland - voting rights are devolved in Scotland and Wales.He wrote: “I just saw an extract of the draft withdrawal agreement. Britain has decided to enfranchise all EU nationals What an odd decision: why offer a blanket deal instead of country by country bilaterals  For what it’s worth, it will signicantly bolster the non-Tory electorate.”At the moment EU citizens cant vote in most UK elections.Citizens rights are still being discussed as part of the ongoing discussions with the bloc.A government spokesperson said: “This is not within the scope of the Withdrawal Agreement. We have always been clear that the voting rights of both UK nationals living in the EU and EU nationals living in the UK should be considered together and that we’re committed to doing bilateral deals to achieve this.”But Theresa Mays soft-Brexit plans would be far better, it said, with growth of up to . per cent.Negotiations are still ongoing about our future with the EU - and talks are deadlocked over Northern Ireland and the border.If a deal isnt signed within three weeks, Mrs May will be forced to enact emergency No Deal planning for businesses across the country, it was revealed yesterday.

title: man demand poppy removed outside home
story: The man, believed to be aged in his s, complained after the poppy was attached to a lamppost in Woodville, Derbyshire.They have been installed across the area by the Royal British Legion ahead of the th anniversary of the end of the war next month.South Derbyshire councillor Steve Taylor was confronted by the OAP while attaching the poppy.He told Derby : A man, in his s, comes outside and told us: You can take that away.We asked him: Do you know what it is for  It is for the th anniversary of the end of the war.He said: I couldnt give a damn. I wasnt born then. If you put it up then it will be gone by the morning.He and a fellow councillor decided the remove the poppy but have been left shocked by the mans reaction.And the pensioner has now been slammed by Mick Golder, chairman of the Swadlincote district branch of the Royal British Legion, who said the poppies are a symbol of the soldiers sacrice.He said: The poppies are there because of the sacrice of all the soldiers who unfortunately died.Our motto this year is thank you to everyone who made the sacrice, and for someone to have that attitude, to me personally, is disgusting but then again we live in a free country.It shouldnt matteryou werent born during the war. It is about sacrice.The British Legion describes the poppy as a “symbol of remembrance and hope” with many people wearing them on October  -  days before Remembrance Day.

title: man hiding 10 pound notes around uk
story: Matt Callanan has spent £, of his own money on a project he hopes will inspire people to do good deeds.So far film-maker Matt has left hundreds of envelopes scattered across Cardf and Dublin, and is planing to target cities in England and Scotland in the future.His project Tenner For Good involves putting a £ or € note in an envelope with two important rules.Number one: Don#t spend the money on yourself. Number Two: Do some good with it.Matt stashes the cash in creative spots across the cities, including in bicycle wheels and on roadworks signs.He tries to place them in spots close to charity shops as a nudge to people who pick them up.In one instance he hid an envelope outside a children#s hospital under a bench.Matt told the Huffington Post: “[A man who works in the hospital] saw the envelope, went back in to the workplace, told them the story and they all started chipping in tenners.“He got to £ and he thought: what can we do for the kids #They turned it into  Easter eggs and he went back dressed as a bunny and delivered all the eggs to the kids in the hospital.”He added: “I love that domino effect that you can create.“I think my favourite one that’s come out of it, there was this guy in Bristol and he didn’t find any of the tenners but he heard about it and wanted to do his own.“He brought this homeless guy into his house, listened to his story, gave him a cup of tea and on the way out gave him a couple of tenners, wished him well, and then the guy got back in touch with him a few weeks after that and said that he’d now got his benefits sorted, a job sorted and a house sorted.“And it was all because this guy Ben had given him his time and made him feel valued. That was just a lovely outcome.”Matt also teamed up with a local troop of Brownies to deliver #thank you# cards to doctors and nurses at a local hospital.He said: “And apparently all of these doctors and nurses ended up bursting into tears because it was just such a kind thing for these young girls to do for them.”

title: mum pretended single working benefits
story: Edyta Ratecka, , claimed she was a single mum but was caught out by family snaps she posted on Facebook showing her enjoying holidays with her boyfriend.Polish-born Ratecka had claimed she was a single mum after giving birth to twins in  to swindle £, over a three year period.She was told by a judge she knew what she was doing because she worked in the benefits department of Cardf Council.Ratecka was today handed a -week suspended sentence after pleading guilty to fraudulent activity, making a  representation to obtain benefits, and of dishonesty failing to noty a change in circumstances.Cardf Crown Court heard how the mum began claiming benefits in  while living with Daniel Thomas but a probe was launched when the social media pictures surfaced.She claimed her boyfriend had moved in to help her after the birth of their sons - now aged five - but described their relationship as not good.Ratecka said she knew it was wrong to continue claiming benefits but insisted she had no option as Mr Thomas was not providing for her.Her lawyer, John Lewis, said she was now relying on her -year-old daughter to keep a roof over her head.Sentencing, Judge Tracey Lloyd-Clarke said: “You were working for a benefit section of Cardf council so you were aware of what you were doing.As well as a suspended prison sentence, she was ordered to carry out  hours unpaid work, complete a six-day rehabilitation activity requirement, and to pay £.

title: map reveals european holiday hotspots earthquakes volcanoes seismic activity
story: But some regions - many considered among some of the best holiday destinations in the world - are at much greater risk of deadly events linked to seismic activity.Just last night, a huge . magnitude earthquake tore through the Greek holiday isle of Zante, ripping up roads and buildings filled with holidaymakers.British Geological Survey seismologist Margarita Segou told The Sun Online: Greece and Italy have the largest seismic hazard, as we say, which means that earthquakes are more frequent there.However, we have cases of big earthquakes in other countries in historical times, such as Spain.The reason why Greece and Italy are the most seismic areas in Europe is they are areas where seismic plates are forming. The African plate is subdacting, going under, and the European plate we say itsabout cm a year.So all this middle and southern Mediterranean is a very active zone, so it has produced many earthquakes in historical times and in the present.We have stories collected from historical times from a large earthquake magnitude . offshore near Crete in AD which produced a tsunami and reached even Egypt.We have another in AD near Sicily, which devastated some cities in Sicily and caused a tsunami.Large scale earthquakes will continue to go ahead in Italy and Greece. But not only big earthquakes are associated with big risk.She cited last years . magnitude earthquake which struck central Italy as one example of a moderate tremor that can cause carnage.This hit on January  a few kilometres northwest of the town of LAquila, killing  people and laying waste to several ancient towns.She added: Risk comes even from moderate earthquakes, they tend to happen every five years in these countries. They are more frequent than large ones.Last year scientists said they expected an increase in earthquakes due to a tiny decrease in the speed of the planets rotation.A report presented at the Geological Society of America argued that five periods of intense seismic activity throughout history have followed periods of when the Earths rotation slowed.However, Segou did not believe the frequency of the tremors hitting Europe was increasing.Associate Professor of Earthquake Science in the School of Earth Sciences at the University of Melbourne, Mark Quigley has previously told news.au central Italy is experiencing crustal extension.He says: Eastern central Italy is moving to the NE relative to Rome.As a result, this region experiences normal faulting earthquakes as the land is torn apart. The fault systems are short and structurally complex, so the earthquakes are not overly large by global standards.But because the earthquakes are shallow and structurally complex, and because many of the local towns and cities contain vulnerable buildings, strong shaking from these earthquakes has the potential to inflict major damage and loss of le in urban areas.Some  per cent occur around the rim of the Pacic Ocean.The plates - giant rock slabs that make up the Earths upper layer - are always slowly moving.They often collide and slide against each other, according to National Geographic.This impact can be unnoticeable on the surface but can cause immense stress between the plates.When this stress is released, it causes massive vibrations, called seismic waves, often hundreds of miles through the rock to the surface.There are fears that there is a big one on the way after a flurry of volcanic activity in the Pacics Ring of Fire.A study from Calornia says that the cluster of tremors around the planets so-called Ring of Fire- a horseshoe-shaped geological disaster zone - could indicate the big one is due to hit.The research, published in the journal Science Advances, involved analysis of  major earthquakes around the Pacic Ring of Fire between  and .Europe also has a number of volcanoes - some dormant, others active - which have in the past caused catastrophic events and huge loss of le.Among these is Mount Etna, on Sicily, which was first recorded erupting in BC, and has exploded around  times since.This last occurred in  when a BBC crew were pelted with boiling rocks and steam as they filmed the mountainside.Many in Europe also remember the  eruptions of Eyjafjallajökull, in Iceland, which triggered huge air travel disruptions across western and northern Europe.Last year, researchers at the University of Leeds revealed the findings of a study which determined such ash cloud eruptions could occur once every  years.Co-author Dr Graeme Swindles said: In , when Eyjafjallajökull erupted, people were really shocked – it seemed to come completely out of the blue, but the eruption of Grímsvötn, the following year, was an extraordinary coincidence.Although it is possible that ash clouds can occur on an annual basis, the averageinterval for the last , years is around  years.The last time volcanic ash clouds affected northern Europe before the recent event was in ,  years ago – but aviation was much less intense at that time and it simply didnt have the same sort of impact.Our research shows that, over thousands of years, these sorts of incidents are not that rare – but people wondering how likely it is that the  chaos will be repeated in the next few years can feel somewhat reassured.Just this year alone the world has witnessed destructive eruptions in Hawaii, Bali and Guatemala.However, Clive Oppenheimer, professor of volcanology at the University of Cambridge, says there has not been an increase in volcanic activity.He told The : There have been quite a few eruptions in the news lately, so people question whether there’s an increase in rates of volcanism that we’re seeing just now, and this isn’t really the case.Eruptions are happening all the time - some make the news headlines and others don’t.If we look at the statistics back in time, the main thing we see is a reporting bias. There are not many eruptions during World War Two, for example, when people had other things to really worry about.So of course things will flare up in one place or another place and then it will be very much how those eruptions affect people and whereabouts in the world - whether that then becomes newsworthy.

title: sewage drinking water thames bosses
story: Thames Water said today the UKs capital will lose £ million a daydramatic measures arent put in place to save the citys water supply.The population of London is set to rise by two million people in the next  years which could lead to a million litre daily shortfall of water, made worse by climate change reducing natural resources.So Thames Water plans to open a reuse plant at the Deephams Sewage Treatment Works in North East London which will turn sewage into water clean enough to drink - a UK first, the Evening Standard reports.But the plant is not currently planned for everyday use - its intended for times of projected or actual drought.Discussions with the Environment Agency are ongoing about the viability of this plan.After plans to build a new £.billion reservoir in Oxfordshire were rejected by the government in , the plan is being revived by Thames Water.It is intended for water to be shipped down the Thames along the Oxford Canal to ensure taps keep flowing.The reservoir near Abingdon would play a vital role in supplying water to the South East.It will be complete by ,the government approves it.Thames Water also owns the UKs only desalination plant in Beckton, East London, which turns sea water into million litres of drinking water a day during drought.The company has a water resources management plan for the next  years which has budgeted £.billion until .A spokesperson said Thames Water is pledging to reduce leakage from its ,-mile network of pipes.He added: “More needs to be done to protect Londoners from the risk of severe drought.“Restrictions on water use in London alone could cost more than £million a day.”The reuse plant will put million litres of water a day back into the system by passing treated sewage through a desalination membrane to clean it.Its then mixed with reservoir water, treated again and pumped into the network.The spokesperson added: “We wouldn’t consider reusewe didn’t think the water would be good enough.”

title: dad convinced telly possessed turns on weird messages
story: Eerie footage captures the scene that unfolded after he checked his home surveillance equipment.At the beginning of the clip, all seems normal in the familys living room - until the television appears to switch itself on.It then flicks through several channels before the video cuts out.The footage, titled My TV turned on by itself was uploaded to Reddit.Recalling the spooky encounter the dad said: “This happened about five minutes after I locked the door and went to bed.‘My we, who is pregnant, was already in our room asleep.“There was no one  in the house – especially behind the curtains – and the remote has a full battery.”But other users were not convinced.One wrote:  [There] has to be a reasonable explanation.”Another claimed: “Maybe someone was messing with you from outside ”

title: mcdonalds human poo london newham
story: Disgusted Ben Terry posted a picture of the human poo on the chains Facebook page.The image shows what appears to be a small piece of excrement lying on the toilet floor at the outlet in Forest Gate, Newham.Wet tissues are scattered beside it on the floor, which appears to be wet.Ben wrote: Actual human poo on the floor in Forest Gate McDonalds. Absolutely disgusting.“How can you expect people to eat food here and they cant even clean the toilet properly.A spokesman for McDonalds said the toilets were immediately closed for cleaning following the shock find.He added: “Cleanliness and hygiene is of the utmost importance to us and we can confirm that as soon as this incident was brought to the attention of our restaurant manager the toilets were immediately closed for cleaning.The incident was resolved quickly and professionally by our restaurant crew.”This is not the first time human excrement has been found on the toilet floor of a McDonalds.Earlier this year, Steven Jackson filmed himself walking into a toilet cubicle in Bristol to find a rather unpleasant surprise.The video shows a huge pile of faeces lying beside the toilet on the floor.

story: Just two out of  famous acquaintances contacted by The Sun responded as calls were made for the -year-old to be stripped of his knighthood.And both chose to distance themselves from the Topshop boss.Despite being former best pals, media baron Richard Desmond claimed he had not “spoken to him or seen him in three years”.It comes after his former PA Samantha Watson called Philip “the worst person I have ever met” and accused him of routinely bullying and viciously insulting her.Hollywood actress Gwyneth Paltrow, who attended Philip’s th birthday party in Monaco in , also appeared to wash her hands of him.In a statement, her rep said: “She hasn’t seen or spoken to him in many years.”Gwyneth recently thanked her ex-boyfriend Brad Pitt for threatening to “kill” Harvey Weinstein when he allegedly sexually harassed her in a hotel room in .Stars including Liz Hurley, Naomi Campbell, Sienna Miller, Cara Delevigne, Leonardo Di Caprio, Tony Blair, Bill Clinton and Tom Jones all refused to pledge any allegiance with Philip.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain fracking lancashire halted earthquake
story: The stoppage came just  days after the gas extraction restarted following a seven-year pause.The tremor was classed as a red event under the fracking regulation traffic-light scheme because it exceeded . magnitude.Sixteen tremors have been recorded in the area by the ­British Geological Survey since October , but none this large.A spokesman for the BGS said the quake was “right on top” of the site, adding: “It’s been caused by the fracking.”Under the rules, work must stop for  hours while monitoring is carried out.Cuadrilla, the energy company fracking at the Preston New Road site in Little Plumpton, Lancs, described the quake as “micro seismic”.It added: “Events such as these result in tiny movements that are way below anything that would be felt at surface, much less cause any harm or damage.”Workers were hydraulically fracturing shale rock when the tremor was recorded near a well km underground at .am.The controversial work had started again after an environmental campaigner failed to block it at the High Court. It is the first fracking to take place in the UK since , when Cuadrilla’s work near Blackpool was halted following two quakes.Friends of the Earth’s Rose Dickinson said: “When is the Government going to realise fracking is the wrong choice for Lancashire, the UK and our global climate ”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince charles wanted call off wedding diana
story: In a new biography, he describes how he wanted to break off his engagement to the aristocrats daughter when I discovered how awful the prospects were.In the explosive book, serialised in the Daily Mail ,Charles describes himself as being permanently between the devil and the deep blue sea ahead of his  nuptials.Author Robert Jobson has accompanied the prince for  months on tours around the world.The book, Charles at Seventy: Thoughts, Hopes and Dreams, marks Charles th birthday in November.Jobson says that Charles knew he and Diana were not suited within just a handful of meetings.He wrote in the Mail: During the weeks leading up to the wedding, he told friends, he would try to talk to her about his work commitments and what kind of day he’d just had — and Diana would stare back at him blankly.The more he saw of his volatile fiancee, the more Charles knew in his heart that he’d made a terrible mistake.That the Prince went ahead with the marriage, despite his firm conviction that it was a mistake, is something he deeply regrets to this day.According to Jobson, Charles wants to challenge pernicious lies about him which he believes were orchestrated by Diana.Charles doubts over the wedding are bound to shock some people.Until now, its been reported that it was Diana who wanted to call off the wedding.Earlier this month the Sun Online told how, just hours before marrying Charles, Diana suffered a bulimic attack.The revelations have been made in Charles, The Misunderstood Prince, written by Sally Bedell Smith, where she details the hours leading up to the big day.Diana’s struggles with bulimia are now common knowledge, with the late princess opening up about her eating disorder in recorded tapes.The book says: “On her wedding eve at Clarence House, Diana could hear the spectacular fireworks celebrations in Hyde Park.“Unknown to even her sister Jane, who stayed with her, Diana had a bulimic attack and was sick as a parrot.The same book also tells how Charles was having second thoughts, which he relayed to his valet, Stephen Barry.The book says: “He did not share the exuberance on display outside the Palace.“Rather, he was in a contemplative mood.“As he listened to the choruses of Rule Britannia, Charles found himself weeping. Stephen Barry asked what was wrong.“Stephen,” he said, “Is it possible to love two women at the same time ”Despite both their fears, the pair tied the knot in front of a congregation of , people, with some  million tuning in to watch the event on TV.But Camilla Parker-Bowles would be a thorn in Diana’s side throughout her marriage to Prince Charles.She saw her as the other woman, and it was later revealed the pair had a relationship while Princes Charles was still married.In her explosive interview with Martin Bashir, Princess Diana infamously said there were “three people” in her marriage.Prince Charles later went on to marry Camilla in , but she refrains from using the title the Princess of Wales out of respect for Diana.

title: pfi repayments 18bn
story: New research from Labour campaigner Stella Creasy claimed local authorities will pay out an extraordinary £ billion over the next two–to-five years in repayments for buildings funded by Private Finance Initiative .Some £. billion will go on interest payments to contractors.Ms Creasy urged the Treasury to force firms to negotiate a “debt consolidation” to slash the interest bill and free up cash to invest back into public services.She said cutting interest on PFI repayments for schools and hospitals by councils and the NHS would generate as much as £ million a year.The move comes days after The Sun revealed the Chancellor will review the use of PFI in major infrastructure projects in the Budget.Under PFI – or Private Finance Initiative – the state or town hall hires a firm to build a school, hospital or sports hall then pays a set fee every year to lease it back. In many cases the ‘debt’ has been sold onto a third party.Ms Creasy told The Sun: “The Chancellor talks about reviewing PFI for the future but our schools and hospitals are struggling and cutting services now.“PFI companies are the payday lenders of the public sector and for too long Governments of all colours have borrowed from these high cost creditors.“Not only should we stop using these kinds of PFI deals, we should also tackle the damage done.”PFI was launched by Sir John Major’s Conservative government  before exploding under Tony Blair’s Labour. There are an estimated  PFIcontracts with a capital value of £ billion up and running.The Department for Transport is using PFI to finance a bypass around Stonehenge.The Treasury last night declined to comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what time do clocks go back
story: At am on Sunday, October , the clocks go back by an hour to transition into Greenwich Mean Time .The clocks go back at am on Sunday, October , .The change signals the coming of winter by making sure there’s more daylight in the mornings and less in the evenings.Plus, when they go back it means you GAIN an hours sleep.But beware, your smartphone and other internet-connected devices should automatically update but many clocks in your home and car will not.When the clocks change again, at am on March  to be precise, youll lose those previous  minutes of gained sleep time, as the clocks go forward.The EU wants to stop changing the time twice a year.In September, the European Commission published a proposal to end seasonal time changes across the continent, andit becomes law we could stop changing as soon as next year.Commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker said: “Millions responded and [they] believe that in future, summer time should be year-round, and thats what will happen.The planned schedule clashes with the Brexit deadline in March , although its currently unclear how this could affect the UK.British Summer Time came into existence with the Summer Time Act that was passed by Parliament in .Germany was the first country to adopt the plan on April , , and on May , Britain followed suit, during the height of the First World War.The campaign which led to the creation of BST and Daylight Savings Timewas started by William Willett in  in a bid to stop people wasting valuable hours of light in the summer months.By setting the clocks back in winter, Brits get an earlier sunrise and earlier sunset.In summer the sun rises and sets one hour later than it would without daylight saving.In a pamphlet called The Waste of Daylight Willett suggested clocks should be advanced by  minutes over four stages in April, and reversed the same way in September.Supporters at the time of the proposal argued the scheme would save energy by reducing domestic coal consumption.They also said it would increase supplies available for the huge manufacturing cost of the war effort.It has been in place ever since – despite criticism from some groups.We wont see lighter days again until Sunday st March  when the clocks will wind forward again at am and British Summer Time begins.Critics say darker mornings are dangerous for kids walking to school and the energy saving argument may be invalidpeople switch on fans and air-conditioning units during the lighter, warmer evenings. title: tory mps including universal credit
story: NewsTory MPs including Universal Credit architect Iain Duncan Smith could lose their seats amid backlash over rolloutAmong those are high profile former ministers including Amber Rudd and Iain Duncan Smith - the architect of the governments flagship welfare schemeShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  OCT NewsIain Duncan Smith has himself said UC needs another £billion to make it work "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAround  Tory MPs could lose their seats amid the backlash over Universal Credit, a study has warned. Ministers including Secretary of State for Wales Alun Cairns, Environment Minister George Eustice and Work and Pensions Minister Alok Sharma could also be rejected at the polls. Analysis by campaign group  degrees shows these constituencies have more people who could be moved onto Universal Credit - potentially losing them money - than the MPs majority. If just a fth of those affected are Conservative voters who switch their vote, the Conservative party could lose so many seats at any election they struggle to work even a minority government.  It comes as a public spending watchdog found Universal Credit is causing “unacceptable hardship” for many of its claimants. The Public Accounts Committee said the Tory “fortress mentality” is failing claimants who are struggling to adapt. Universal Credit, which is being rolled out gradually, replaces six existing benefits with a single payment - but critics have argued the programme, which has been subject to several delays, is flawed. A report by the Child Poverty Action Group suggests single parents face a cut in their income of pound, a year, families with two children could lose pound, on average and families with three children face a cut of pound,.Despite being the architect of UC, Iain Duncan-Smith has himself quit the Cabinet over welfare cuts and has demanded another poundbillion be pumped into Universal Credit to make it work. While former Tory PM Sir John Major has warned it could become Theresa Mays poll tax which sparked riots and helped lead to her downfall.  The research comes after more than , people signed a  Degrees petition to Chancellor Philip Hammond, calling on him to put more money into the Universal Credit system. Charlotte Woodworth, Campaigns Director at  Degrees, said: Tens of thousands of people have called on the Chancellor to ease the pain of Universal Credit.And hundreds of  Degrees members affected by Universal Credit have emailed their MPs to share their fears. While the concern about its effects is widespread, this analysis shows the government also face a political cost.The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. Our analysis found that in  Conservative-held constituencies, the number of people who could see their income reduced is five times greater than the majority of the current MP. Our calculations found thatjust a fth of those affected are Conservative voters who switch their vote, Theresa May’s government could be in deep trouble.  degrees members are calling on the Chancellor to use his Budget to give more money to universal credit and so ease the pain families up and down the country are facing.”  Degrees has compared the number of households that are expected to be affected with the parliamentary majorities of the sitting MPs.In  constituencies, there are five times as many households affected as the parliamentary majority of the incumbent MPin the  general election.

Her terried daughter, Gracie, cried out: Mummy, why hasnt he got a head  Ginette had to do a double take and decided to film the strange incident. However, all was not as it seemed, and Ginette ensured she drove around him to show the children it was actually just an elderly man leaning on his walking stick.  She said: It took for us to drive past him to see that he did indeed have a head. After Gracie pointed him out, I have to admit I had to do a double take too. I jokingly said he has come out early for Halloween. We love Halloween in our family. I have three very excited kids ready to get dressed up. He hasnt given the kids any inspiration though - Oskah is being a monster again this year.  Ginette and her family had been out shopping last Saturday near Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, when they spotted the elderly man. She explained: It was Saturday afternoon and we were driving through Huthwaite. We were going shopping with the children when Gracie goes mummy, why hasnt he got a head  They were stunned. We made a joke out of it and were all laughing. I didnt really want her to think there were headless men wandering around the streets, especially on the run up to Halloween with all the clowns and Michael Myers. I would say he was in his eighties, easily, and he was walking for ages - he was very slow. As we drove back up on our way back the kids were looking out for him.

title: inspirational words turned jobless teens
story: NewsInspirational words that turned jobless teens le around after she refused to claim benefitsJordanna, from Manchester, said an off-the-cuff comment changed her le after living in fear of being accused of "sponging"ShareCommentsByBeth Abbit:,  OCT NewsJordanna now works for the NHS "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager has revealed how an off-the-cuff comment turned her le around after she was left jobless and refused to claim benefits.Jordanna was left without an income at  after becoming ill and dropping out of college. But she refused to sign on, blaming confusion about her future and embarrassment about sponging. She told Manchester Evening News: “I was not claiming benefits because I didn’t want to be seen as sponging. I wanted to find my own way. “My nana said I just needed to find my feet. I knew I wanted to do something in public services. “I just ended up stayed at home and doing nothing. “I dragged it out. I was scared I was going to be judged. It became harder the longer it went on.” Aged , she started working in a department store, but hated the job and was confused about what to do next after dropping out of college. The situation lasted for a year, and it was only when a neighbour suggested she see a talent coach called Anthony Vanterpool that things began to change.  She said: “By the time I got in touch with him I was not confident at all. I was not where I wanted to be and I didn’t know how to get there.” He explained: She needed quite a bit of reassurance back then. “She was very fixated on not wanting to let people down and didn’t want to be put under pressure. “Between leaving college and meeting me something had sapped her confidence away. We lost all focus and direction and didn’t know where she wanted to go.” Together Anthony and Jordanna wrote up her CV and started to talk about her career options. In the end, it was an off-the-cuff comment that convinced Jordanna she could change her le. Anthony told her: All progress will place you outside your comfort zone. You are what you make yourself.” From then on Jordanna embarked on a health and social care course with the support of GM Talent Match, which forced her to mix with people of dferent ages and backgrounds and tackle any problems head on. “I was not quite sure how I would take to it but from day one I really enjoyed it,” she said. When Jordanna struggled with a classmate she decided to face up to the woman and confront the problem - something which has had a lasting impact.  She said: “I never would have been able to do that before. It was challenging but I faced up to it. “I always used to question myself and I didn’t like confrontation and when anything did happen I couldn’t face it head on. Now I can.” The -year-old now works long shts as a clinical support worker at one of Greater Manchester’s biggest hospitals and has helped to save lives - both in her personal and professional le. When a friend was attacked on a night out and knocked unconscious Jordanna called , stabilised her friend and went with her in the ambulance. She now has ambitions to become a paramedic herself. “This job is something I enjoy and it’s really rewarding,” Jordanna said. “It’s a challenge but it’s worth it. “But young people do need help. I do think to myself, ‘ I hadn’t had this help, where would I be today ’” Mr Vanterpool said a lot of young people he helps are held back by barriers, including illiteracy, poverty and mental health problems. He explained: “I think it’s a lot to do with peers and who you socialise with, plus your family network. “If you don’t have your own aspirations you may look at other people’s aspirations and then you find thats not what they really want. It’s about unpicking that. “A lot of it is down to that fear factor - fear of failure, being embarrassed andyou’ve not got anyone steering you it can be really dficult.” Unfortunately, the dficulties Jordanna faced in her teenage years are not uncommon. As such, Greater Manchester Talent Match is calling on local authorities to be better resourced to track young people past the mandatory age of . The Big Lottery-funded programme, which offers one-to-one, long-term support to unemployed young people, is due to end. Experts are applying for further funding but are worried young people will be left without support. “For a city region of Greater Manchester’s status and ambition, it isn’t acceptable to have young people fall through the cracks with their potential and ambitions unrealised,” Talent Match programme manager Marie Graham said. “These iniduals personal growth and fulfilment also has huge positive knock-on effects to communities and society as a whole.”
